summary: What's news world-wide for April 6, 2010
None

headline: What's News: Business & Finance
summary: What's News: Business & Finance Top Stories for April 6

headline: North Korea Sentences U.S. Man
summary: North Korea said that it had sentenced an American to eight years' hard labor and fined him approximately $700,000 for illegally entering the country.

headline: Apollo Ends Park Merger Pact
summary: Apollo Global Management terminated its $650 million leveraged buyout of theme-park operator Cedar Fair, after shareholders threatened to vote down the deal.

headline: Hainan is Playground for China's Rich
summary: The organizers of Hainan Rendez-Vous at the island's Sanya resort did their part to boost the area's image this past weekend with an extravaganza of private jets, top-end autos, luxury properties and yachts.

headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections & Amplifications for April 7.

headline: California Cap-Trade Faces Fight
summary: The energy industry and an antitax group plan a ballot challenge to California's cap on greenhouse-gas emissions, saying the effort would lead to job losses and raise energy prices if it goes into effect in 2012.

headline: Corporate Watch
summary: Corporate Watch

headline: China Welcomes Delay of U.S. Report on Currency Policy
summary: Chinese government-backed economists said Beijing welcomed a U.S. decision to delay its report on exchange-rate policies, in another sign that bilateral ties are under repair ahead of a meeting between leaders of the two powers next week.

headline: Gomez to Lead Los Angeles Archdiocese
summary: Pope Benedict XVI named Archbishop José Gomez to take over the archdiocese of Los Angeles, the nation's largest. He will succeed the retiring Cardinal Roger Mahony in February.

headline: Retailers Expect Strong Sales
summary: Retailers are expected to show strong sales growth for March, bolstering hopes that consumers are poised to join the economic recovery.

headline: New Tapes Surface in Chevron Case
summary: The tables appear to have been turned on a former Chevron contractor who secretly recorded a judge in a long-running lawsuit in Ecuador over environmental damages.

headline: AutoNation Lifts First-Quarter Forecast
summary: AutoNation increased its forecast for profitability in the first quarter, a sign that the auto retailer is seeing continued gradual improvement from the bottom of the recession.

headline: Pensions Press GM, Chrysler
summary: GM and Chrysler may need to contribute "substantial" sums to their employee pension plans in coming years to comply with U.S. laws, the Government Accountability Office said.

headline: HTC's Profit Rises 3.1%
summary: HTC said its first-quarter net profit rose 3.1%, as the Taiwan company posted better-than-expected sales of smart phones amid improving consumer demand.

headline: Verizon CEO Cool to Merger
summary: Despite recent reports of talks about a joint venture with Vodafone, Ivan Seidenberg says he sees little reason to strike a deal.

headline: Sears CEO's Pay Falls 20%
summary: Sears' interim CEO received a pay package worth $1.5 million in 2009, down 20% from a year earlier. But his base pay has been raised again for 2010.

headline: GOP Senators Step Up Attacks on Appellate Court Nominee
summary: Senate Republicans stepped up attacks on an Obama nominee to a federal appeals court, previewing what could be opposition-party tactics should the president have a Supreme Court vacancy to fill later this year.

headline: Prius Claims Japanese Crown
summary: Toyota's Prius retained its crown as Japan's best-selling car in March and became the first hybrid to hold the top spot through the Japanese fiscal year ended that month.

headline: Total Probed for Alleged Corruption
summary: A French investigating magistrate has put Total under formal investigation over suspected bribery in connection with the oil major's involvement in the U.N.'s' Oil-for-Food program in Iraq during the late 1990s and early 2000s.

headline: 'AIG' Resort Finds a Buyer
summary: Hedge fund Washington Real Estate Holdings has purchased Citigroup's equity control of the St. Regis Monarch Beach, the luxury resort made infamous by AIG's aborted plans to host a sales conference there in 2008.

headline: Yelp Changes Site Reviews
summary: Yelp, a business-review Web site, is changing some features amid criticism and lawsuits over how certain comments were promoted and others filtered out.

headline: FAA Criticizes LAX for Persistent Runway Hazards
summary: Federal aviation regulators criticized Los Angeles International Airport's management for balking at proposed fixes to reduce runway collision risks.

headline: Daimler, Renault Set to Detail Pact
summary: Daimler and Renault will host a press conference in Brussels Wednesday, where they are widely expected to lay out details of an alliance between the companies and Japan's Nissan Motor.

headline: Michael Dunne: Toyota's Loss Isn't Quite China's Gain
summary: Carmakers in the Middle Kingdom have a very long way to go before they are competitive abroad.

headline: Malone Bows Out of DirecTV
summary: Prompted by an FCC demand, John Malone will exchange his large voting stake in DirecTV to a small holding of Class A shares. He will also step down as chairman.

headline: Deadly Mine Blast Likely to Intensify Federal Scrutiny
summary: A deadly blast at a Massey Energy coal mine in West Virginia Monday is expected to intensify government examination of underground coal mining, and could tighten near-term supplies of the type of coal used by steelmakers.

headline: Brief Boost for Stocks Wanes
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average floundered in its latest attempt to reach 11000 as a burst of afternoon buying spurred by comforting words from the Federal Reserve ran out.

headline: Debate Reopens on Overhaul of U.S. Spy Agencies
summary: A former U.S. spy chief, Mike McConnell, reopened the debate over the government's intelligence structure Tuesday, calling for the formation of a Department of Intelligence that would put the existing 16 intelligence agencies under one department.

headline: We Certainly Lag In Bang for the Buck
summary: My major point is that for spending 50% to 100% more than our peers on health care, overall we achieve roughly equivalent medical outcomes with somewhat inferior outcomes in measures such as life expectancy, prematurity, and neonatal mortality,

headline: Tragedy in West Virginia
summary: Rescue efforts were temporarily halted Tuesday morning after an explosion at a coal mine in southern West Virginia left 25 people dead in the worst U.S. mine disaster in more than two decades.

headline: Europe Returns With Renewed Optimism
summary: Shares hit a 2010 high, as investors back from Easter break had their first chance to react to signs the U.S. economy could be on track for a sustainable recovery. In the Americas, Mexico stocks hit a record.

headline: Siebert Brandford HiresEx-New York Official
summary: Former New York City Comptroller William Thompson, who lost a bid to unseat Mayor Michael Bloomberg last fall, is joining Siebert Brandford Shank & Co.

summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

headline: Regional Banks Outperform Broader Market
summary: Shares of regional banks climbed amid investor confidence in the sector, helping the stocks outperform the broader market.

headline: Consumer-Agency Plan Is Proposed
summary: Aides to Republican Sen. Richard Shelby floated a proposal last week to Democratic staffers that would create an independent consumer-protection agency, reversing course from a previous Republican position.

headline: Banks Steal the Options Show
summary: The options market played host to several interesting trades in banks, including regional players Regions Financial and U.S. Bancorp.

headline: Playing Japan Against Canada
summary: The Canadian dollar's parity with the greenback is grabbing headlines, but there's another currency that provides an even starker growth contrast: the Japanese yen.

headline: Finra Fines Citigroup $650,000
summary: Finra fined Citigroup $650,000 for disclosure and supervisory violations in the authority's first enforcement action involving a broker-dealer stock borrow program.

headline: Building Spending  Continues Decline
summary: Despite some signs of an improving economy, spending on new construction continued to decline in early 2010. The total value of construction spending was running at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $846.2 billion in February, down 1.3% from January and down 13% from February a year ago. Spending on residential construction was running at an annual rate of $258.5 billion in February, down 3.8% from a year earlier, while spending on nonresidential construction was $587.7 billion, down 16% from a year earlier.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: Writing in the Daily Beast on April 4, Tunku Varadarajan says to leave the pope alone.

headline: Toyota Extends Buyer Incentives
summary: Toyota extended its March customer-incentive program into April and broadened its complimentary maintenance program to all buyers, as the auto maker seeks to maintain sales momentum in the face of its recall crisis.

headline: NYSE Plans Interest-Rate Futures
summary: NYSE Euronext's plan to introduce a family of U.S. interest-rate futures in the third quarter will put it up against sector heavyweight CME Group and upstart ELX Futures.

headline: Crude Ekes Out Small Gains
summary: Crude-oil futures closed up slightly ahead of energy supply data, showing continued upward momentum from a recent string of strong economic reports.

headline: Polish Insurer Sets IPO Plans
summary: Polish insurer Powszechny Zaklad Ubezpieczen formally unveiled its plans for an initial public offering on the Warsaw Stock Exchange Tuesday, in a transaction that is set to be one of the largest in Europe in the second quarter.

summary: Maoist rebels killed dozens of paramilitary soldiers in the dense forests of central India's Chhattisgarh state, the group's deadliest attack against the Indian government in the four-decades-old insurgency.

headline: European Stocks Finish Higher
summary: Investors largely shrugged off another round of Greece-related fretting to push European stock markets to their highest levels in 18 months or more, boosted by strong economic readings out of the U.S. over the region's long Easter break. The euro lost ground against the dollar, and Greek stocks fell.

headline: New York's Car Culture
summary: The Museum of the City of New York takes a look back at the unlikely romance between the automobile industry and Manhattan with its new exhibition, "Cars, Culture, and the City." Here's a peek at the exhibit, which is on view through Aug. 8.

headline: Gold Climbs Above $1,135
summary: Gold futures managed slight gains as investors bought the metal as an inflation hedge and safe haven while fresh worries about Greek finances also boosted the U.S. dollar.

summary: The launch of the British election campaign marks an important step toward providing Bank of England policy-makers with some much needed clarity on how the public sector's huge budget deficit will be cut.

summary: A number of buyout firms and some payment-processing and information-technology firms are bidding for RBS's Global Merchant Services business.

summary: The German car maker made it profitably through the recession, but it won't cover its cost of capital anytime soon, so there may be better value elsewhere in the European auto sector.

summary: Will Mahinda Rajapaksa choose to secure his own future or that of Sri Lanka?

summary: Indian students could go to foreign universities—without leaving India.

summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia Tuesday raised its key policy rate for a fifth time since October 2009, highlighting again its concerns about rising house prices in an economy now well entrenched in recovery.

summary: Investors should be careful before they rev up Hero Honda Motors any further.

summary: Spanish jobless claims rose again in March as Spain suffered from an unusually harsh winter and one of Europe's longest-running recessions.

summary: Australia's benchmark stock index touched an 18-month high despite an increase in interest rates as hope for growing demand fueled a rally in resources shares. The Nikkei fell 0.4%.

summary: Samsung said operating profit could hit a new high as sales continue to improve, signaling that the company is set to spearhead the global consumer-electronics industry's recovery this year.

summary: Analysts anticipate the U.S. recovery to take center stage in markets this year, as rising interest rates and 2009's outperformance make emerging markets less attractive for investors.

summary: The gut renovation of Julia Angwin's brownstone in New York City's Harlem neighborhood is underway, but she and her husband have spent about half of the contingency fund they had set aside for overruns.

summary: Unitech, one of India's top real-estate developers, appointed advisers to restructure its operations as an expanding economy boosts demand for property.

summary: AT&T said it plans to invest about $1 billion this year to better serve its big business customers world-wide and small businesses in the U.S.

headline: Tensions Flare Outside of Terre'Blanche Trial
summary: Whites and blacks faced off angrily in front of a heavily guarded courthouse where a teenager and another farm worker who allegedly confessed to killing white supremacist leader Eugene Terre'blanche appeared.

headline: Godrej Consumer to Buy Indonesian Firm
summary: Godrej Consumer Products said it has entered into an agreement to acquire Indonesia's PT Megasari Makmur Group and its distribution company for an undisclosed amount.

summary: British Prime Minister Gordon Brown announced the country will go to the polls on May 6, setting up a tight election battle over the U.K.'s battered economy and soaring deficit that could result in political gridlock.

headline: Sanofi Settles More Patent Suits
summary: French drug maker Sanofi-Aventis said it has settled more patent infringement suits with generic drug makers over its cancer drug Eloxatin.

summary: Indonesia's central bank kept its key policy rate steady at 6.5% and again signaled that it will keep interest rates low for the next few months, given the benign inflation outlook.

summary: The founder of Maguire Properties is offering to take over three of the company's office buildings, saying he is concerned they could wind up in default.

summary: Apartment rents rose during the first quarter, ending five straight quarters of declines and signaling the worst may be over for the hard-hit sector.

summary: New York-based Och-Ziff Capital Management's main hedge funds posted gains in March, and the firm's assets under management grew by $700 million.

summary: The odds appear slim that Greece will find sizeable demand from Asia for its upcoming global bond offering

headline: Fannie, Freddie Touch Off Swaps Scrap
summary: The regulator of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac plans to have the mortgage-finance giants use a clearinghouse for interest-rate swaps trade by year's end. Wall Street banks and exchanges are scrambling.

summary: U.S. regulators plan to fine Toyota $16.4 million for allegedly hiding gas-pedal problems from safety regulators. It would be by far the largest civil penalty ever imposed against an auto maker.

summary: Faced with regulatory issues, Entergy is backing away from its plan to spin off five nuclear power plants into a separate company.

headline: Doctors Face Retesting for Certification
summary: For the first time since leaving medical school, many doctors are facing renewal of board certification in their fields—147 specialties from dermatology to obstetrics.

summary: After finally re-joining the work force, many individuals find that a long bout of unemployment has left its mark in the form of anxiety about the new job.

summary: Small-capitalization stocks surged Monday, as data showing improvements in the labor and housing markets broadly strengthened confidence in riskier assets.

headline: Signs of Recovery Lift Oil, Copper
summary: Oil and copper ended at heights not seen since 2008, boosted by evidence that the U.S. economy is recovering just as the two commodities enter their peak demand period.

headline: Jordan's King Issues Rebuke to Israel
summary: Bilateral relations are at their lowest point since a 1994 peace treaty, King Abdullah says, amid new construction in East Jerusalem.

headline: Gutted House, Gutted Budget
summary: The brownstone is bare, and our columnist's contingency budget is disappearing. How an innocuous walk-through cost nearly $30,000.

summary: U.S. ban on Mexican trucks cheers drivers, but Mexico's retaliatory tariffs trigger cutbacks at Wisconsin paper plant.

headline: Craig Barrett: The Case for Common Educational Standards
summary: In 1950, 60% of the jobs required no particular skills. The world has changed.

headline: McGurn: The Pope and the New York Times
summary: Cardinal Ratzinger did more than anyone to hold abusers accountable.

headline: Chiquita's Fruitful Strategy
summary: The food company has stopped selling bananas to some unprofitable buyers and implemented a fuel surcharge, while also expanding into packaged foods.

summary: The U.S. Treasury secretary will meet China's vice premier in Beijing, a surprise meeting amid speculation that China is considering adjusting its exchange-rate policy.

summary: The service sector grew for the fourth consecutive month in March, according to a report, the latest indicator that the economic recovery is broadening to more businesses and industries.

headline: IPad Sales Fall Short of Hopes
summary: Apple said it sold more than 300,000 iPads in the U.S. on the first day the device went on sale, tempering Wall Street's highflying expectations for the much-hyped multimedia tablet computer.

headline: U.S. Keeps First-Strike Nuclear Strategy
summary: The administration is releasing a new nuclear-weapons strategy that makes only modest changes, while Russia says it reserves the right to withdraw from its new arms-control treaty if it feels threatened by a U.S. missile-defense shield.

summary: Hospital admissions for heart attack were 23% lower in 2007 than in 2002, according to a just-published analysis of Medicare data.

summary: UAL and US Airways have resumed talks of a potential merger that would create a global airline behemoth.

summary: US Airways said its passenger unit revenue rose about 18% in March from a year earlier,  adding to evidence the airline industry is recovering from last year's recession-induced plunge in demand.

summary: Herewith I propose a contest to invent the next panic.

summary: U.S. and U.K. prosecutors are investigating a prominent Canadian businessman for criminal money laundering and bribery as part of a two-year investigation centering on Alcoa.

summary: Desensitized by everything from Facebook to reality TV, people are sharing way too much personal information with their colleagues.

summary: The FDA approved a reformulated version of the powerful painkiller OxyContin that is designed to make it harder to abuse.

summary: Tens of thousands of jobless Americans could lose unemployment benefits after Congress failed to enact a short-term extension, with Democratic and Republican lawmakers exchanging blame.

summary: President Cristina Kirchner's government was preparing to tap central bank reserves to make a payment to bondholders this week.

summary: Stocks climbed to fresh 18-month highs Monday, with American Express, Caterpillar and Chevron among the gainers.
